recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Second Presbyterian Church was organized in 1818 due to a split (brought on by disagreements over doctrine and renting pews) in the First Presbyterian Church's congregation. They built their first church on the west side of Prince (now Market) Street in 1820. The congregation grew quickly and moved to a larger building on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Market Street in 1860. The area around the church grew more congested as Knoxville grew, and the congregation sold their Market Street property and moved to a new building on the corner of Clinch and Walnut in 1905. The congregation eventually outgrew this building as well, and moved to a structure on Kingston Pike in 1957.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay and Clinch (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. The Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Imperial Hotel was built on the corner of Gay and Clinch Streets in about 1894. It replaced several older businesses, including the Hotel Hattie. The Imperial burned down in 1916 and was replaced by the "completely fireproof" Farragut Hotel in 1919.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Four children playing on the front lawn of Mrs. Jane Kennedy's home. General James White built part of the house itself (the first in Knoxville) in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to proctect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J.Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. It was intended to provide a cultural education and enjoyed a reputation as one of the South's best schools. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s, and now houses a number of educational programs including adult education, the adult high school, GED testing, and continuing education.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: In the early 20th century, popular theory held that this building, located on Cumberland Avenue, was the first state capitol of Tennessee. There is, however, no evidence to support this claim - indeed, several astute commentators have pointed out that this structure was not built until after the capital had moved to Middle Tennessee. In any case, the building was razed in January of 1927.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: George Wesley Pickle built the Pickle Mansion (sometimes called Confederate Hall and Fort Sanders Hall) at 1633 Clinch Avenue in 1889. The structure was severely damaged by fire in 2003, but plans have been made to restore it. Pickle himself was a veteran of the Confederate Second Tennessee Infantry and served as Tennessee's Attorney General and Reporter of the State from 1886 to 1902.

mods.abstract: View of the W.M. Fulton house, built in 1928. According to Victor A. Hyde, this home is located in an A-type community: one "occupied by white inhabitants, having a value of $10,000 or more." Weston Miller Fulton himself (1871-1946) was exceptionally wealthy, having invented a number of useful (and profitable) gadgets.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: View of single-family home located at 1205 W. Clinch Avenue in Knoxville, Tennessee. According to Victor A. Hyde, this residence is located in a B-type district, which he defines as one "occupied by white occupants, in which the residences range in value from $2,500 to $10,000." These communities generally separate wealthy A-type communities from poorer C-type communities.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Wonderland Park resort community (including the Wonderland Hotel) was created in Elkmont in 1912 to rival the Appalachian Club's nearby resort area. The Wonderland Park Hotel and its associated buildings became the Wonderland Club in 1914 when they were sold to a group of private investors from Knoxville. Most of these private owners managed to obtain lifetime leases when the Great Smoky Mountains National Park was created. The majority of these leases were eventually converted to 20-year leases that were later extended to expire in 1992. The Wonderland Hotel ceased operations when its lease expired and collapsed in 2005 while debate over what to do with the historic structures standing in Elkmont raged. Although salvage efforts were discussed, the hotel was demolished in late 2006.

mods.abstract: Businessman Edward Jackson Sanford and his wife, Emma Chavannes, bought this home from Knoxville businessman and politician James Hervey Cowan in 1890. Originally known as "River Lawn," the Sanfords renamed the property "Maplehurst" because of the several maple trees growing on the property. Sanford died in 1902, and in 1912 his estate sold the property to Alex McMillan & Co. for development.

mods.abstract: Perez Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830, where he quickly became an extremely popular and successful merchant. He had this elegant home at the corner of Main and Locust Streets built in 1831. After his death in 1901, C.B. Atkin bought the house and made several additions, including a front portico in the classic colonial style. The structure was demolished in about 1950.

mods.abstract: The Lamar House Hotel was built in 1817. The Bijou Theatre opened as part of that hotel on March 8, 1909. Over the years, it hosted many famous vaudeville and theater acts. By 2005, however, the Theater was deteriorating and its owners defaulted on their mortgage. Knoxvillians, including Mayor Bill Haslam, banded together to save the Theater and fundraising and renovation efforts are ongoing.

mods.abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Tennessee's first governor, John Sevier, and his wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried on the lawn.

mods.abstract: William Blount (who signed the US Constitution and served as the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River) and his wife Mary commissioned this home in 1792. In addition to its impressive size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple led a campaign to preserve Blount Mansion in the early 1920s, and the house became a museum in 1925. It was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1965.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Henry Edward Goetz, founder of the Goetz Sanitarium, was born to Edward and Sarah Jane (Hawn) Goetz on February 16, 1874 in Louisville, Tennessee. He attended the Bell House School and the University of Tennessee before graduating from the Tennessee Medical College in 1905. He married Beatrice Hollister on January 24, 1898, and the couple had at least three children: Royal Frank, Beatrice, and Helena. Goetz did postgraduate work in 1906 and eventually specialized in otolaryngology. He later became interested in narcotics addicts and attended a special course in mental and nervous diseases in New York in 1913. He founded the Goetz Sanitarium on North Broadway upon his return to Knoxville. He moved his hospital to the Fountain Head Hotel in 1917, and continued to work here until his death following the removal of a brain tumor on December 2, 1927.

mods.abstract: Captain Thomas Tomlinson built the Tate Springs Hotel in the late 1800s near one of the mineral springs flowing from Clinch Mountain in Grainger County. The resort, which featured cottages, stables, a golf course, and a park, was extremely prosperous until the Great Depression. The original structure was torn down in 1936 and the property was sold to Kingswood School in 1941. Today, the only remnant of the hotel is a gazebo standing near the mineral spring.

titleInfo.title: Corner of Melrose Street and Cumberland Avenue

mods.abstract: View of the intersection of Melrose Avenue and Cumberland Avenue, showing the entrance to a residential neighborhood and a set of electric streetcar tracks. Melrose Park was originally an upscale Knoxville residential neighborhood. The University of Tennessee acquired the area in the 1960s and began destroying its Victorian-era homes to allow for University expansion in the late 1970s. Although several homes were adapted to house University programs, few traces of the area's original character remain today.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Charles J. McClung built Oakwood Mansion for his son, Matthew McClung, in 1870. The house changed hands in 1873, when it became home to Matthew's sister Lucy and her husband, Jacob Lytton Thomas. The home was then located at the outskirts of town, allowing Thomas to farm and raise livestock. Railroad contractor Henry H. Thrasher purchased the house in about 1905 and remodeled it completely, adding porches, columns, and the brick exterior. He sold it in the late 1920s to a group of physicians, who renamed it the Howard-Henderson Hospital. It was briefly known as the Acuff Clinic before becoming the Kingston Pike Motel in the late 1950s. When that enterprise failed, the structure was remodeled and reopened as the Kingston Pike Nursing Home. It continued in this capacity until the early 1990s. It was home to a number of businesses, including a beauty parlor and a restaurant, before Sam Furrow purchased it in 1999. The structure currently serves as office space for a number of enterprises.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Charles J. McClung built Oakwood Mansion for his son, Matthew McClung, in 1870. The house changed hands in 1873, when it became home to Matthew's sister Lucy and her husband, Jacob Lytton Thomas. The home was then located at the outskirts of town, allowing Thomas to farm and raise livestock. Railroad contractor Henry H. Thrasher purchased the house in about 1905 and remodeled it completely, adding porches, columns, and the brick exterior. He sold it in the late 1920s to a group of physicians, who renamed it the Howard-Henderson Hospital. It was briefly known as the Acuff Clinic before becoming the Kingston Pike Motel in the late 1950s. When that enterprise failed, the structure was remodeled and reopened as the Kingston Pike Nursing Home. It continued in this capacity until the early 1990s. It was home to a number of businesses, including a beauty parlor and a restaurant, before Sam Furrow purchased it in 1999. The structure currently serves as office space for a number of enterprises.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Charles J. McClung, Franklin H. McClung, and James Cowan operated an extremely successful dry goods wholesale business called Cowan, McClung, and Co. in central Knoxville during the early part of the 20th century. Built in 1875, this home was designed by Nashville architect P.J. Williamson and stood on Main Avenue until it was destroyed in about 1964.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Wallace K. McClure purchased this home on Temple Avenue (now Volunteer Boulevard) from Henry H. Ingersoll in 1902. He and his family lived in the house until his death in 1921. In 1941, Wallace McClure Jr. donated the house to the University of Tennessee as part of the W.K. McClure Foundation for the Study of World Affairs that he had founded as a memorial for his father. The house was demolished in the 1960s.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: John Chisholm built this structure, which he operated as Chisholm's Tavern, on land he bought from James White in 1792. He sold the property sometime before 1800. In this photograph, the building is shown in use as a multi-family residence. The edifice was razed in December of 1966.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Standing at 1505 Highland Avenue, this house belonged to Knoxville author James Rufus Agee's father, Hugh James Agee. This structure appears in Agee's autobiographical A Death in the Family (1957).

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Christian Union Community Club was formed in about 1918 and disbanded in 1929. The building shown was later used for other benevolent purposes, including a WPA night school and a Junior League Day Nursery.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Knoxville's first YMCA was organized in 1854 at the Second Presbyterian Church. The organization moved to this structure, standing on the corner of Commerce and State, in 1900. They continued to meet here until 1929, when they moved to a newer edifice on the corner of Locust and Clinch.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Tenement standing in what is now downtown Knoxville. The Andrew Johnson Hotel is visible in the left background.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: View of the front entrance to Knoxville's old City Hall. The building was constructed in 1844 and originally housed the Tennessee School for the Deaf. It served as a makeshift hospital for both Union and Confederate troops during the Civil War but returned to its original purpose when the war ended. It became Knoxville's City Hall in 1924, and continued in this function until 1980. The structure is now listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

name.namePart: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Photographic Center

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Knoxville Civic Auditorium and Coliseum opened in the fall of 1961. Built with musical performances in mind, it seats 2,500 people and offers a 57 foot by 54 foot stage. It has also hosted such non-musical entertainments as circuses and ice shows.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Perez Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830, where he quickly became an extremely popular and successful merchant. He had this elegant home at the corner of Main and Locust Streets built in 1831. After his death in 1901, C.B. Atkin bought the house and made several additions, including a front portico in the classic colonial style. The structure was demolished in about 1950.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Colonel James Van Deventer and his family lived in this home on Temple Avenue (now called Volunteer Boulevard) from approximately 1900 until 1908. The University of Tennessee later used the structure as its Faculty Club, and the building was finally razed in the 1980s to allow for the construction of Hodges Library.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: John Craighead constructed the Craighead-Jackson House in 1818. After Robert Craighead II sold the property in 1855, the structure passed through many hands and fell into serious disrepair. In the late 1950s, the Blount Mansion Association arranged for the home's restoration. The edifice opened as a museum on 3 April 1966 and was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1973. This museum also houses William Perry "Buck" Toms' collection of 18th century silver, said to be the finest in the Southeast.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Both Governor Blount's home and office were built in 1792. Although the home was restored and opened as a museum in the early 1920s, the office was not repaired until 1955. It currently serves as part of the Blount Mansion museum.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Unidentified home in what appears to be a middle-class section of Knoxville. Unfortunately, no identifying information about the house or the small boy on the path in the yard is available.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Brothers Charles and George Swan founded Swan Brothers Bakery in 1883. They were originally located on Central Street and operated a stall in Knoxville's Market House. The company acquired what became their main facility on the 1800 block of Magnolia Avenue (shown) in 1928, where they continued to operate until being acquired by the American Bread Company in 1989. The bakery finally closed in 1991 and the buildings were auctioned in 1992.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The East Tennessee Female Institute was founded in 1828. The academy offered such courses as arithmetic, orthography, reading, music, penmanship, astronomy, chemistry, and latin. The institute was merged with the Knoxville public school system in 1882, and this building was demolished in 1889.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: George Wesley Pickle built the Pickle Mansion (sometimes called Confederate Hall and Fort Sanders Hall) at 1633 Clinch Avenue in 1889. The structure was severely damaged by fire in 2003, but plans have been made to restore it. Pickle himself was a veteran of the Confederate Second Tennessee Infantry and served as Tennessee's Attorney General and Reporter of the State from 1886 to 1902.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Bradley Drug Co. and Co-Operative Drug Co. Inc.

mods.abstract: The Bradley Drug Co. was founded in 1917 and had moved to its quarters at 624 S. Gay Street in downtown Knoxville by 1920. The Co-Operative Drug Co. Inc. replaced it in 1925, but went out of business in under a year.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Residence of Charles and Nellie Ross

mods.abstract: This house, which stood on Rose Avenue in Knoxville, Tennessee, was home to Professor Charles C. Ross beginning in 1891. His sister Nellie lived with him from 1895 until she married James Milton Bailey in 1898. Another (currently unidentified) individual may also have occupied the house during this time. Charles Ross, Nellie Ross, and an illegible name are inscribed on the back of the picture.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Empire Building was constructed at the corner of Prince Street (now Market Street) and Church Street in 1901. Such diverse interests as labor unions, insurance agents, and lawyers rented space in this "fireproof" building.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: William D. Kuhlman opened the first of his chain of drugstores at 301 Gay Street in 1894. The store pictured, Kuhlman's Drug Store No. 2, opened at 600 S. Gay Street in 1905. It closed in 1909, but later re-opened at 607 S. Gay Street. Kuhlman eventually established three additional stores: one at 310 W. Clinch Avenue, one at 322 N. Gay Street, and one on S. Gay Street near the Tennessee River Bridge.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Richard F. Graf designed and built this house at 325 Woodlawn Pike in about 1923. The Graf family lived in this home for many years before Dr. J.P. Cullum acquired it. Graf and several of his sons operated the architecture firm R.F. Graf & Sons in downtown Knoxville from 1910 until 1942.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Central Methodist Episcopal Church South, designed by Chattanooga architect R.H. Hunt, was dedicated in March of 1927. It represented a combination of two older Knoxville Methodist congregations: Broad Street and Centenary. The church was renamed Central United Methodist Church when the United Methodist Church was formed in 1968. Although membership has dwindled, the church continues to operate today.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The University of Tennessee built the 21-story Kingston Apartments in 1968 in order to accommodate its rapidly expanding student population. The building served as married and graduate student housing until 2006, when New York developer Stanley Mohr bought the property with plans to turn it into a private apartment building.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks Home was originally located at 421 W. Main Avenue. The Elks moved to the Home pictured here in 1909, when Colonel J.Y. Johnston took over the Main Avenue property to use as his private residence. This picture is a copy of a postcard that was mailed in 1909.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Although the congregation was established in the 1790s, the original First Presbyterian Church building (called the "Brick Meeting House" was not finished until 1816. This structure was replaced by the one shown here in 1855. This building was razed in 1901 in order to allow for the construction of a larger facility.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Knoxville Sentinel was founded in 1886 and merged with the Knoxville News to form the Knoxville News-Sentinel in 1926. This image shows the Sentinel building in the early 1920s, including the electric streetcars that ran past it and one of the towers where policemen controlled traffic lights.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: John Fanz Staub designed this home at 1820 Melrose Avenue for his aunt, Emma Fanz Price Hope, in 1921. Completed in 1924, the home reflects Mrs. Hope's fondness for the cottage architecture of England's Cotswold District. The University of Tennessee purchased the home in 1980, and Staub oversaw its renovation just before his death in 1981. The building now houses the University's distinguished visitors.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church, South

mods.abstract: When the Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church South building (constructed in 1875) was destroyed by fire in 1928, the structure shown replaced it. Although the new building stood at the corner of Henley and Main Streets, the congregation chose to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name was changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968, and this structure continues to operate as a Methodist Church today.

titleInfo.title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church, South

mods.abstract: This building is the second of the two Southern Methodist Episcopal Churches that stood on Church Street between 1836 and 1928. It was built in 1875 and burned down in 1928. After the fire, the congregation elected to build a new structure on the corner of Henley and Main Streets, which continues to operate today.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: When Mrs. Martha C. Henson died in 1927, she left the University of Tennessee $200,000 to be used for the betterment of the school's female students. The money was used to build a women's dormitory, which opened in 1930 and was named Henson Hall in her honor. The building housed Air Cadet Training Program students from 1943 until June of 1944, but returned to housing women as soon as the program ended. It became an academic building in the late 1970s, and continues to serve in this capacity today.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: This bridge, which crosses the Tennessee River in western Knoxville, was built in the late 1800s. It was condemned in about 1922 and later destroyed.

titleInfo.title: Interior of the Whittle Springs Hotel

mods.abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Greek immigrants George and Frank Regas started the Regas Brothers Cafe (originally known as the Astor Cafe) on Gay Street in 1919. The restaurant stayed open 24 hours a day, except for Christmas Eve and part of Christmas Day. The Regas family continues to operate the eatery, now called Regas Restaurant, today.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Brookside Cotton Mills was founded in 1885. By 1902, it was Knoxville's largest employer with 1,200 employees. The mill ceased operations in 1956, and the last of its buildings was destroyed in 1997. The Development Corporation of Knox County purchased the property in 2006 with the intention of redeveloping it.

mods.abstract: Interior of an unidentified metal processing plant. This image most likely depicts one of ALCOA's operations, as this corporation is the largest producer of such products in the East Tennessee area.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Cherokee Textile Mills was founded in Knoxville, Tennessee in 1917. It produced fine cotton goods on a contract basis. The Mill moved from Knoxville to Sevierville, Tennessee, in 1954 as a result of Sevierville's 1951 decision to issue revenue bonds to attract nonlocal business.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960. This image shows the market's meat section in the early 20th century.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

mods.abstract: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960. This image shows a stall in the market's meat section, which advertises the "finest meat ever offered for sale in Tenn."

A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960. This image shows the stalls of two of Knoxville's most prominent bakers, Kern's and Swan's, as well as W.E. Bradley's vegetable stall.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Lobby of the St. James Hotel

mods.abstract: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, the St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center: WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at the St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

mods.abstract: The Tennessee Theater opened to the public on October 1, 1928. It featured such luxuries as brocade draperies, crystal chandeliers, carpeted draperies, and an ornate dome. This photograph was taken during a radio exhibit featured during the Theater's first month of operation.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Lamar House Hotel was built in 1817. The Bijou Theatre opened as part of that hotel on March 8, 1909. Over the years, it hosted many famous vaudeville and theater acts. By 2005, however, the Theater was deteriorating and its owners defaulted on their mortgage. Knoxvillians, including Mayor Bill Haslam, banded together to save the Theater and fundraising and renovation efforts are ongoing. This photograph was taken between Acts II and III of _Little Johnny Jones_ on the Bijou's opening night.

mods.abstract: This bridge was built in 1876 in order to allow traffic on Gay Street to travel over the railroad tracks. It was replaced in 1919 when Gay Street's northern end was raised by 15 feet and a viaduct was constructed. A number of shops moved to locations under the new viaduct, where they prospered for many years. Unfortunately, the structure gradually fell into disrepair and was closed for demolition in November of 2005. It was replaced by a concrete viaduct in late 2006, which remains in use today.

mods.abstract: Perez Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830, where he quickly became an extremely popular and successful merchant. He purchased Williams Island (located in the Tennessee River) in 1869. Here, he constructed a manor house and established Island Home Farm. He raised crops of fruits and vegetables until his death in 1901.

mods.abstract: George Campbell Brown was born to Lizinka Campbell and James Percy Brown on November 27, 1840. He served in the Confederate Army during the Civil War and later operated his family's farm, called Ewell Farm, in Spring Hill (Maury County) Tennessee. Under his management, the farm expanded into one of the region's most prosperous plantations. After his death on July 30, 1893, his son Lucius Polk Brown took over the thriving family business.

mods.abstract: Plan showing the original layout of the city of Knoxville, drawn in about 1791. A number of the city's earliest families are represented on this map, including Humes, Henley, Cowan, McClung, Camp, Beardin, Blount, Strong, Crozier, and Craighead. The section designated "graveyard" at the bottom left survives as the graveyard as the First Presbyterian Church. The original document is available in the Special Collections Library.

titleInfo.title: View of the Tennesse River from the UT Agricultural Experiment Station

mods.abstract: The University of Tennessee's Agricultural Experiment Station was established in 1882 with the intention of furthering agricultural research in the state. It grew quickly, and by 1900 branch stations were being built so that research could be conducted under specific local conditions. Today, these stations continue to research numerous topics and provide important contributions to agricultural science in Tennessee and around the world.

titleInfo.title: Gladiolas on C.L. Baum's Bearden Farm

mods.abstract: German immigrant Charles L. Baum opened his first florist shop in 1889 at 319 W. Clinch Avenue. The business proved extremely successful, and Baum was able to expand considerably over the years. This image shows gladiolas on Baum's 65-acre farm in Bearden, Tennessee.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Weston Fulton, inventor of the Sylphon Bellows, founded Fulton Sylphon in Knoxville in 1904. It manufactured primarily valves and gages, including a thermostat vital to depth charges during World War I and a part crucial to bomb sights during World War II. The company was later sold to Reynolds Metals and then to Robertshaw and Siebe. It also gradually lost its prominence in the field. In 1994, what remained of the business was purchased by Texas leveraged buyout specialist J. Randal Greaves, and its name was changed to Fulton Bellows and Components to reflect its origins. Now known simply as Fulton Bellows LLC and owned by Morris Capital Management Group (which purchased it in August of 2004), the company continues to operate in Knoxville today.

titleInfo.title: Gay Street Bridge and Tennessee River

mods.abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

mods.abstract: Charles L. Baum opened his florist's shop on Gay Street in 1889. The store introduced this delivery truck (the first panel truck in Knoxville) in 1909. It was apparently quite popular with Baum's customers.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: In the early 1920s, the Honorable S.G. Heiskell hit upon the idea of reinterring Catherine Sevier (wife of former governor John Sevier) in Knoxville. This photograph, probably taken at the site of Sevier's original burial in Russellville, Alabama, shows the Knoxville delegation dispatched to retrieve her remains. Upon their return, Sevier lay in state at the Women's Building and was reinterred with great fanfare on July 27, 1922. Former governor John Sevier's remains had been reinterred in Knoxville in 1889.

mods.abstract: Swimmers in Chilhowee Park's lake. Visible are the extreme left side of the Liberal Arts Building (constructed for the National Conservation Exposition of 1913) and the lake's distinctive walkway. Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

titleInfo.title: Unidentified men in front of building

mods.abstract: Group of fourteen men standing in front of an unidentified building, likely located in Knoxville's downtown commercial district. Their clothing indicates that this picture was taken during the late 19th or early 20th century.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Intersection of Kingston Pike and Scenic Drive during the late 19th century. The Pike began as a 15-mile toll road stretching from Knoxville to Campbell's Station. It had been completely paved by the 1920s and began to develop as a commercial area in the 1930s. It still serves as a major Knoxville thoroughfare today.

mods.abstract: The J.J. Craig Company founded the Candoro Marble Works in South Knoxville in 1914. This business finished marble blocks taken from quarries in Knox, Blount, and Loudon counties in addition to marble imported from around the world. At its peak, it employed about 140 people.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The American Limestone Company was established in 1913 to process some of the rock generated by the zinc mines near Knoxville. In 1971, the American Smelting and Refining Company (ASARCO) bought the American Limestone Company, including all four of its Knoxville mines. It continues to process limestone in East Tennessee today.

mods.abstract: View of an electric streetcar on Knoxville's Lonsdale Line (later called the Washington Avenue Line). This photograph was taken shortly after the electrification of Knoxville's streetcar lines and the formation of the Knoxville Traction Company.

titleInfo.title: Laundry Day in the Lane Street Slums

mods.abstract: View of laundry day in Knoxville's Lane Street slums. According to Hyde, this area represents a C-type community one occupied by caucasians where the total value of the property is $2500 or less. In 1939, the Knoxville Housing Authority was in the process of eliminating such areas as part of a slum clearance program.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Louisville & Nashville railroad yards and terminals

mods.abstract: View of the Louisville & Nashville Railroad yards and terminals. The Commonwealth of Kentucky granted the L&N a charter on March 5, 1850 and the Tennessee State Legislature authorized the railroad's extension to Nashville on December 4, 1851. The railroad began expanding after the Civil War and eventually reached such cities as Knoxville (Tennessee), Montgomery (Alabama), Norton (Virginia), and New Orleans (Louisiana). By the time the Seabord Coastline Railroad bought the L&N in 1971, it operated 6,574 miles of track in 13 states.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Richard "Uncle Dick" Payne (1813-1885) sold water to Knoxvillians from his two-wheeled cart from 1845 until his death in 1885. He was an extremely popular merchant and is generally recognized as Knoxville's first "water works." Payne Street (in the Reservoir Hill area) is named in his honor.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: First electric streetcar to Lake Ottosee

mods.abstract: Although Knoxville's streetcar system was established in 1876, electric streetcars did not arrive until 1890 when W.C. McAdoo Jr. consolidated the existing streetcar lines into the Knoxville Electric Streetcar Company. McAdoo electrified four lines in all: the Lake Ottosee Line, the Park Avenue Line, the Washington Avenue Line, and the Broadway Line. The streetcar in this image was the first to run on the electrified lines.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: This train, which came from Louisville, Kentucky on the East Tennessee, Virginia & Georgia Railroad, was the first through train to arrive in Knoxville. The ETV&G was formed when the East Tennessee & Georgia Railroad merged with the East Tennessee & Virginia Railroad in 1869. The new railroad expanded significantly before merging with the Richmond and Danville Railroad to form the Southern Railway in 1895.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Mary Baum, Minnie Baum, and Mr. Wood (general agent for the Tennessee Central Railroad Office) in front of C.L. Baum's florist shop. German immigrant Charles L. Baum (Mary and Minnie's father) opened this extremely successful business in 1889 at 319 W. Clinch Avenue.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal: to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Aerial view of Knoxville published by Raphael Tuck & Sons, "art publishers to their majesties the King and Queen." Visible are the third Gay Street Bridge, the Tennessee River, the Courthouse, and the First Baptist Church's spire.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Andrew Johnson Hotel opened on Gay Street in 1929 and prospered throughout the Great Depression. Its numerous guests included Jean Paul Sarte, Duke Ellington, Amelia Erhart, Liberace, Tony Perkins, and Sergei Rachmaninoff. Knox County purchased the building in 1990, and is considering selling the property for a mix of residential and commercial uses as of June 2007.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay and Clinch (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. The Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Portrait, residence, and office of "Parson" Brownlow

mods.abstract: Controversial Methodist preacher and newspaperman William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow was born in 1805 in Wythe County, Virginia. His zest for confrontation and staunch Union loyalties convinced the Confederacy to expel him from Tennessee during the Civil War, but he returned to Tennessee in March of 1865 when he was elected governor. During his term, Brownlow convinced the legislature to ratify the 14th Amendment (thus sparing Tennessee from Reconstruction) and made great progress toward restoring the State's economic health. He served one term in the US Senate before dying in 1877.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Circle Park neighborhood was home to many of Knoxville's richest and most prominent citizens during the early part of the 20th century. The area began to decline in the 1940s, and the University of Tennessee bought most of the neighborhood in the 1950s. Between 1960 and 1968, the University razed the original structures to make way for such buildings as the Andy Holt Tower and the McClung Museum, many of which are still in use.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Knoxville's first YMCA was organized in 1854 at the Second Presbyterian Church. The organization moved to this structure, standing on the corner of Commerce and State, in 1900. They continued to meet here until 1929, when they moved to a newer edifice on the corner of Locust and Clinch.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks Home was originally located at 421 W. Main Avenue. The Elks moved to the Home pictured here in 1909, when Colonel J.Y. Johnston took over the Main Avenue property to use as his private residence. This postcard was mailed in 1909.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: This marble quarry was located approximately one mile south of Knoxville, Tennessee. Although marble is no longer produced in East Tennessee, it was a major industry at the time this postcard was mailed.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Although somewhat idealized, this log cabin is of a design typical of the Great Smoky Mountains before the advent of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. This particular view shows the front of the cabin, including steps, a makeshift porch, and a firepit.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Melrose Park was originally an upscale Knoxville residential neighborhood. The University of Tennessee acquired the area in the 1960s and began destroying its Victorian-era homes to allow for University expansion in the late 1970s. Although several homes were adapted to house University programs, few traces of the area's original character remain today.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Second Presbyterian Church was organized in 1818 due to a split (brought on by disagreements over doctrine and renting pews) in the First Presbyterian Church's congregation. They built their first church on the west side of Prince (now Market) Street in 1820. The congregation grew quickly and moved to a larger building on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Market Street in 1860. The area around the church grew more congested as Knoxville grew, and the congregation sold their Market Street property and moved to a new building on the corner of Clinch and Walnut in 1905. The congregation eventually outgrew this building as well, and moved to a structure on Kingston Pike in 1957.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: In the early 20th century, popular theory held that this building, located on Cumberland Avenue, was the first state capitol of Tennessee. There is, however, no evidence to support this claim - indeed, several astute commentators have pointed out that this structure was not built until after the capital had moved to Middle Tennessee. In any case, the building was razed in January of 1927.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

titleInfo.title: Chilhowee Park (near Machinery and Liberal Arts Building)

mods.abstract: The Machinery and Liberal Arts Building was constructed in Chilhowee Park as part of the 1913 National Conservation Exposition. Although this event dealt only with local issues, it was an ambitious attempt to educate citizens and businessmen about the importance of conserving natural resources. The Exposition was sponsored by President Theodore Roosevelt and continued previous efforts in the field.

titleInfo.title: East Main Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church

mods.abstract: East Main Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church was built in about 1900 at 1249 East Main Avenue. It was replaced by Mount Olive Baptist Church in 1947, and the Knoxville Coliseum stands on the site today.

mods.abstract: View of Knoxville taken from the western side of the city. A number of private homes are visible in the foreground, and downtown (including the Holston Bank Building) can be seen on the horizon.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, the St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center: WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at the St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Brabson Island, site of Brabson's Ferry Plantation, sits in the French Broad River in Sevier County, Tennessee. Since this postcard was mailed in 1913, the notation "Brabson's Ferry near Knoxville, Tenn." most likely refers to the ferry that crosses the French Broad several miles upstream of Brabson Island rather than to the Plantation or to the island proper. Brabson's Ferry Plantation was added to the National Register of Historic Places on June 25, 1975.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The East Tennessee Female Institute was founded in 1828. The academy offered such courses as arithmetic, orthography, reading, music, penmanship, astronomy, chemistry, and latin. The institute was merged with the Knoxville public school system in 1882, and this building was demolished in 1889.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Knoxville suburb of Fountain City began as a center of religious camp meetings in the 1830s. After the Fountain Head Improvement Company built a three-story hotel in 1886 and the Fountain Head Railroad Company began carrying tourists to the area in 1890, however, it lost its original farming character and became a resort area.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Constructed in 1905, Lincoln Memorial Hospital was closely associated with Lincoln Memorial University's medical program. LMU bought the facility in May of 1909, and its medical program merged with four others to form the University of Tennessee College of Medicine in Memphis in 1911.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Two of the monuments on the courthouse's grounds are visible in this image the obelisk commemorates Tennessee's first governor John Sevier, while the marble archway honors Confederate surgeon John Mason Boyd.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Knoxville's Masonic Temple was originally Charles McClung McGhee's private home. The structure was designed by architect Joseph F. Baumann in 1872 and altered to serve as the Masonic Temple after McGhee's death in 1907. The interior of the home was restored in the early 1990s.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Knoxville General Hospital opened on Cleveland Place in 1902. It served as Knoxville's primary hospital until August of 1956, when it was replaced by the University of Tennessee Memorial Hospital (now the University of Tennessee Medical Center).

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Coal was one of East Tennessee's major industries during the early 20th century. The field began to decline during the 1930s and today the industry is no longer nearly as prominent as it once was.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: In Robert L. Nash's original vision, Talahi was to be not just a park but an entire upper-class subdivision in west Knoxville. He acquired land adjoining Knoxville's new Sequoyah Hills neighborhood in 1926 and began marketing it to potential residents in 1929. Only one lot was sold before the Great Depression, which put an end to Nash's dream. After his 1933 suicide, Sequoyah Hills effectively annexed Talahi, which developed with the rest of the area into one of Knoxville's toniest neighborhoods.

mods.abstract: A bolt of lightning striking Knoxville, Tennessee near the World's Fair Park. Visible structures include the Sunsphere, the United States Pavilion, and the State of Tennessee Amphitheater.

mods.abstract: View down Gay Street, long one of Knoxville's major thoroughfares. Visible are the old Hotel Imperial and one of Knoxville's early electric streetcars.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: View of Clinch Street (looking east from Prince Street). Visible are the old Customs Building, the Fouche Building, and the Holston Building. The building behind the Holston Building would later be razed to make way for the Farragut Hotel.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. The obelisk visible on the courthouse lawn marks the grave of John Sevier, Tennessee's first governor. His wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried nearby.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The first Methodist Episcopal Church was organized shortly after the Civil War by the Reverend J.B. Ford. Their first permanent church, dedicated in 1869, stood on the corner of Clinch and Market Streets. The congregation grew quickly and moved to this church, located on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Locust Street, in 1894. The building was designed in the Romanesque style by architect H.H. Richardson. The Church moved again, this time to the Hugh Sanford property, in 1966 and became the First United Methodist Church when the Methodist Church and the United Evangelical Brethren merged in 1968.

mods.abstract: View on Knoxville's Gay Street. This image was taken near the the site of the Hope Brothers' Jewelry Store and shows the clock that has stood outside the establishment for many years.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: View of Knoxville's Main Avenue, looking west. This street was located in one of Knoxville's upscale residential sections, as demonstrated by the luxurious home standing at the right of the image.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Knoxville's original Public Hall, better known as the Market House, was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House (shown) was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: General James White built this house, the first in Knoxville, in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to protect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Woman's Building was originally constructed in 1897 as the Knoxville Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition in Nashville. The following year, a number of Knox County's women's organizations had the building moved from Nashville to Knoxville's Main Street. Unfortunately, the structure burned in 1906.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Knoxville Banking and Trust Building was completed in 1907 on the site of the original Blount College. It was Knoxville's tallest building until 1912, when it was surpassed by the Holston. C.B. Atkin later purchased the structure, which he enlarged and renamed the Burwell Building in honor of his wife, Mary Burwell. The structure became famous in 1928, when the Tennessee Theater was added as part of an addition standing at 604-606 Gay Street. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1982.

mods.abstract: This hand-colored postcard shows a view of Walnut Street, looking north from Church Street, at the turn of the 20th century.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: This picture was taken shortly after the completion of the Stratford Hotel at 409 Wall Avenue in 1905. Although not as well known as the Andrew Johnson Hotel or the St. James Hotel, the Stratford Hotel operated until 1939. In 1940, it was replaced with the Stratford Hotel Barber Shop.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Park Inn opened in late 1931 in what had been Phi Gamma Delta's Fraternity House at 1541 West Cumberland Avenue. Although it advertised itself as "Knoxville's Outstanding Tourist Home ... Strictly High Class," the enterprise failed in about 1933. Although a private citizen rented out its furnished rooms in 1934, it was once again home to a fraternity (this time Alpha Tau Omega) by 1935.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Henley Street Bridge was built at a cost of $1 million between 1930 and 1932. After the Fort Loudon Dam was completed and its reservoir filled in 1943, the water level in the Tennessee River rose by several feet and so changed the appearance of the bridge. This image shows several of the shoals characteristic of the lower water level.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: This image shows the University of Tennessee's "Hill" as seen from Circle Park. Visible buildings include Old College, North College, Barbara Blount Hall, the YMCA, and some of the residences once located near the campus.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Boaters on Chilhowee Park's lake prior to the 1910 Appalachian Exposition. Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

mods.abstract: Constructed in 1905, Lincoln Memorial Hospital was closely associated with Lincoln Memorial University's medical program. LMU bought the facility outright in May of 1909, and its medical program merged with four others to form the University of Tennessee College of Medicine in Memphis in 1911.

mods.abstract: Central Methodist Episcopal Church South, designed by Chattanooga architect R.H. Hunt, was dedicated in March of 1927. It represented a combination of two older Knoxville Methodist churches: Broad Street and Centenary. The church was renamed Central United Methodist Church when the United Methodist Church was formed in 1968. Although membership has dwindled, the church continues to operate today.

mods.abstract: The Knoxville suburb of Fountain City began as a center of religious camp meetings in the 1830s. After the Fountain Head Improvement Company built a three-story hotel in 1886 and the Fountain Head Railroad Company began carrying tourists to the area in 1890, however, it lost its original farming character and became a resort area. Note that this postcard is an octochrome.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: This Southern Railway Station was built in Knoxville in 1904. It prospered until passenger traffic began to decline in the 1960s due to competition from airplanes and automobiles. The last passenger train to pass through the station was the "Birmingham Special," which departed on August 12, 1970. The station was renovated in the early 1990s for use by Knoxville architectural firm Bullock, Smith, and Partners, Inc.

titleInfo.title: Kingston Pike Entrance to Melrose Park

mods.abstract: Melrose Park was originally an upscale Knoxville residential neighborhood. The University of Tennessee acquired the area in the 1960s and began destroying its Victorian-era homes to allow for University expansion in the late 1970s. Although several homes were adapted to house University programs, few traces of the area's original character remain today.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: When the Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church South building (constructed in 1875) was destroyed by fire in 1928, the structure shown replaced it. Although the new building stood at the corner of Henley and Main Streets, the congregation chose to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name was changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968, and this structure continues to operate as a Methodist Church today.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: St. John's Episcopal Church was organized in Knoxville in 1826. Its original house of worship (on the corner of Walnut and Cumberland streets) was razed in 1891 in order to make way for a larger structure. This building, designed by J.W. Yost, was completed in 1892. When the Diocese of East Tennessee was created in 1986, the Church became St. John's Cathedral. Currently, the Cathedral is one of the only surviving churches in downtown Knoxville.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Grand Army of the Republic Monument

mods.abstract: The first Grand Army of the Republic monument was erected in the northeast corner of Knoxville's National Cemetery in 1901. This memorial featured a column of Tennessee marble topped by a statue of a Union soldier and a bronze eagle with his wings spread. This monument was struck by lightning and destroyed on August 22, 1904. Its replacement, shown here, was completed on October 15, 1906. It features a miniature medieval fortress and a central column topped with a statue of a Union soldier at parade rest. A contemporary local legend identifies him as General John T. Wilder, who was the only ranking general on the memorial committee.

mods.abstract: The Machinery and Liberal Arts Building was constructed in Chilhowee Park as part of the 1913 National Conservation Exposition. Although this event dealt only with local issues, it was an ambitious attempt to educate citizens and businessmen about the importance of conserving natural resources. The Exposition was sponsored by President Theodore Roosevelt and continued previous efforts in the field.

titleInfo.title: Interior of the Appalachian Exposition's Main Building

mods.abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

The original building on the corner of Gay and Vine was replaced by this white marble structure on the corner of Market and Commerce in 1917. It remained in use until 1971, when a new building was constructed.

titleInfo.title: Post Office and Custom House Building

mods.abstract: Completed in 1874, Knoxville's Post Office and Custom House may have been the city's first building to be designed by a professional architect, in this case Alfred B. Mullett. The structure was enlarged in 1910 and operated until a new Post Office was constructed in 1934. The TVA occupied the building until 1976, when it was restored and repurposed as the East Tennessee Historical Center.

mods.abstract: Lewis M.G. Baker and Charles M. Himel established this private school, located on the corner of Highland and 12th Streets, in 1889. It was dedicated to preparing boys for college, and for many years the University of Tennessee and several other schools admitted its graduates without further examination. The school's building was destroyed by fire in 1893 but was replaced by a larger structure later that year. It finally closed in 1913.
