recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Perez Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830, where he quickly became an extremely popular and successful merchant. He purchased Williams Island (located in the Tennessee River) in 1869. Here, he constructed a manor house and established Island Home Farm. He raised crops of fruits and vegetables until his death in 1901.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Until the Louisville & Nashville Railroad gained entrance to Knoxville in 1905, the Southern Railway held a monopoly on rail traffic through the city. This depot was completed in 1906 and featured such amenities as a Ladies' Waiting Room with a private entrance, a fireplace, rocking chairs, and desks complete with L&N stationary. The building was renovated for the 1982 World's Fair and today houses two restaurants opened shortly after the renovation was complete.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The first Methodist Episcopal Church was organized shortly after the Civil War by the Reverend J.B. Ford. Their first permanent church, dedicated in 1869, stood on the corner of Clinch and Market Streets. The congregation grew quickly and moved to this church, located on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Locust Street, in 1894. The building was designed in the Romanesque style by architect H.H. Richardson. The Church moved again, this time to the Hugh Sanford property, in 1966 and became the First United Methodist Church when the Methodist Church and the United Evangelical Brethren merged in 1968.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: East Tennessee Hospital for the Insane

mods.abstract: The East Tennessee Hospital for the Insane opened in 1886 with 99 patients transferred from the older Tennessee Lunatic Asylum in Nashville. In 1920, the facility's name was changed to Eastern State Hospital as part of a program to rename all of the asylums in the state. The facility was updated in 1971 after a number of deficiencies were exposed. The hospital's name was changed again, this time incorporating the phrase "Mental Health Institute," in 1977. It continues to operate as a mental health care center today.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Clay Brown Atkin (1864-1931) built the Hotel Atkin in the late 1870s on Knoxville's Gay Street. Atkin also ran a business manufacturing furniture and mantels, developed a number of other Knoxville and Fountain City properties, and served as director of a number of local organizations.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge. Also visible in this image is Knoxville's courthouse, which was constructed in 1885.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: In early 1892, W.W. Woodruff offered his lot on Deaderick Street and his help raising funds to Knoxville's First Baptist Church in order to organize a new church. The product of these efforts was Centennial Baptist Church (renamed Deaderick Avenue Baptist Church in 1905), which was dedicated on September 13, 1892. The church was destroyed by fire in 1909, but was quickly rebuilt and continued to prosper for many years. Unfortunately, it no longer exists today.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Ralph Lawson Berry founded the Ralph L. Berry Funeral Home on September 20, 1928. His son, Fred O. Berry Sr., joined him in the business in 1934, but problems among the stockholders forced both to resign in 1936. In 1937, Ralph Berry, Fred Berry, and Edward Weigel founded the Berry Funeral Home on South Gay Street. In 1948, the business expanded when the Berry Funeral Home purchased and remodeled a structure (shown here) on Chapman Highway. A number of other major expansions were made in later years (including a merger with SCI Funeral Services of Tennessee) and Berry Funeral Home continues to operate as one of the most prestigious mortuary services in Tennessee.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

mods.abstract: Aerial view of Knoxville, Tennessee showing part of the University of Tennessee campus (including Hoskins Library and Ayres Hall), the Henley Street Bridge, and East Tennessee Baptist Hospital.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: In 1943, a group of East Tennessee Baptists conceived of building a Baptist Hospital in Knoxville to alleviate a pronounced shortage of available hospital beds in that city. The East Tennessee Baptist Hospital was completed in 1948 at a cost of $3,128,000. It provided space for 254 inpatients and was considered one of the most modern hospitals in the South. A number of additions have been made over the years, including the Blount Professional Building, the Baptist Professional Building, a Chapel, the Baptist Medical Tower, a Heart Center, an Eye Institute, a Regional Cancer Center, and several branches. The hospital continues to prosper and serve East Tennessee today.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Medical Arts Building, located on Knoxville's Main Street, was completed in 1930. It was constructed under the direct supervision of the medical profession so that it could be tailored to meet the individual needs of each tenant. For many years, it was considered one of the finest Medical Arts Buildings in the United States. The structure has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places since 1984.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Ayres Hall, named for UT president Brown Ayres, was constructed in 1919 to replace decaying Old College, East College, and West College. Although money was raised to preserve Old College (dear to many alumni) it was discovered that its brick, which had been cheaply made, had decayed to the point that it was unsafe to move and the building was razed. Ayres Hall was dedicated in 1921 and has served as the campus's "landmark building" ever since. Chi Omega donated Ayres' first set of chimes in 1950, which rang every quarter hour until they were stolen by vandals in the early 1970s. The Class of 1991 replaced the chimes as their senior gift, thus reviving the tradition of "telling time by Ayres' chimes."

mods.abstract: Melrose Park was originally an upscale Knoxville residential neighborhood. The University of Tennessee acquired the area in the 1960s and began destroying its Victorian-era homes to allow for University expansion in the late 1970s. Although several homes were adapted to house University programs, few traces of the area's original character remain today.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The first Methodist Episcopal Church was organized shortly after the Civil War by the Reverend J.B. Ford. Their first permanent church, dedicated in 1869, stood on the corner of Clinch and Market Streets. The congregation grew quickly and moved to this church, located on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Locust Street, in 1894. The building was designed in the Romanesque style by architect H.H. Richardson. The Church moved again, this time to the Hugh Sanford property, in 1966 and became the First United Methodist Church when the Methodist Church and the United Evangelical Brethren merged in 1968.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Brothers James and John Moses organized the congregation that would become Knoxville's First Baptist Church in 1843. The church's first permanent house of worship stood on Gay Street and was completed in 1850. The congregation split in 1869, and the dissidents formed Knoxville's Second Baptist Church. The First Baptist Church moved to their second home (made possible in large part by merchant and philanthropist W.W. Woodruff) in 1888. Their current house of worship, located at the corner of Walnut and Main Streets, was completed in 1924 and is still in use today. It was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1997.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Visible in the background is the Hotel Andrew Johnson.

mods.abstract: This Southern Railway Station was built in Knoxville in 1904. It prospered until passenger traffic began to decline in the 1960s due to competition from airplanes and automobiles. The last passenger train to pass through the station was the "Birmingham Special," which departed on August 12, 1970. The station was renovated in the early 1990s for use by Knoxville architectural firm Bullock, Smith, and Partners, Inc.

mods.abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

titleInfo.title: Drawing room in the Blount Mansion

mods.abstract: William Blount (who signed the US Constitution and served as the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River) and his wife Mary commissioned this home in 1792. In addition to its size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple led a campaign to preserve Blount Mansion in the early 1920s, and the house became a museum in 1925. The portraits on the far wall show William Blount (left) and his half-brother Willie Blount.

titleInfo.title: Knoxville Traction Company Reservoir and Power House

mods.abstract: The Knoxville Traction Company was chartered on March 31, 1898 and eventually operated some 60 electric streetcars on 30 miles of track. It became part of the Knoxville Railway and Light Company when all transit and electric operations were consolidated in 1908. The eventual successor of this organization, the Knoxville Utilities Board (KUB), continues to serve the city today.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Island Park in Bluff City, Tennessee

mods.abstract: Bluff City, located on the Holston River between Bristol and Johnson City, was originally known as Choate's (also spelled Shoate's) Ford for Edward Choate, one of its first white settlers. It was often used as a river crossing, as it lay on several popular overland routes. The town's name was changed to Middletown in 1793 and again to Union Depot (later shortened to Depot) in 1859 when the East Tennessee and Virginia Railroad came through. The town was known as Zollicoffer (for the Confederate general of that name) during the Civil War, but reverted to Union at the War's end. It was finally named Bluff City in 1887.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Controversial Methodist preacher and newspaperman William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow was born in 1805 in Wythe County, Virginia. His zest for confrontation and staunch Union loyalties convinced the Confederacy to expel him from Tennessee during the Civil War, but he returned to Tennessee in March of 1865 when he was elected governor. During his term, Brownlow convinced the legislature to ratify the 14th Amendment (thus sparing Tennessee from Reconstruction) and made great progress toward restoring the State's economic health. He served one term in the US Senate before dying in 1877.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Charles McClung built Kingston Pike in 1792. He also commissioned the first home to be built along the Pike, which he named "Statesview." Over the years, other wealthy Knoxvillians built more homes along the road, including Drury P. Armstrong's "Crescent Bend" (1832), Robert H. Armstrong's "Bleak House" (1856), and J.E. Lutz's "Westwood" (1890). Although the Pike has been heavily developed during the 20th century, some portions retain their original residential character.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: East Tennessee Deaf and Dumb School

mods.abstract: The Tennessee Deaf and Dumb School (whose name changed to the Tennessee School for the Deaf in 1925) was established in Knoxville in 1844. The original campus was the Churchwell House, but the school soon moved to land donated by C.M. McClung near the center of town. After closing during the Civil War, the school expanded quickly during the Reconstruction Era. By 1922, the institution had outgrown its quarters and moved to what had been the Dickinson Estate in South Knoxville. As in previous years, both the campus and its programs expanded quickly. The school continues to serve an important role in Tennessee's educational system today.

mods.abstract: The TVA built Fort Loudon Dam, the uppermost of the dams on the Tennessee River, between 1940 and 1944 in order to control floods, aid navigation, create electric power, and ensure adequate water supply. The finished dam is 125 feet high and 4,190 feet long. The lake it creates serves as a popular recreation area.

mods.abstract: General James White built this house, the first in Knoxville, in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to protect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

mods.abstract: This motor court catered to Knoxville travelers when Kingston Pike was the main thoroughfare through the city. It was closed in the mid-1960s and destroyed in the late 1970s to make way for a CVS drugstore.

mods.abstract: Knoxville's old City Hall was constructed in 1844 and originally housed the Tennessee School for the Deaf. It served as a makeshift hospital for both Union and Confederate troops during the Civil War but returned to its original purpose when the war ended. It became Knoxville's City Hall in 1924, and continued in this function until 1980. The structure is now listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Knoxville's English Lutheran Church was founded in 1888 and formally incorporated in 1890. It was designed to serve those Lutherans who preferred to worship using English rather than German. The church's congregation grew quickly, and this building was constructed on the corner of Broadway and Emory Streets in 1913. Mrs. Martha Henson donated most of the money for the structure in memory of her late husband, James A. Henson. The building is now known as St. John's Lutheran Church and has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places since April of 1985.

mods.abstract: Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

mods.abstract: John Sevier was born in 1745 in Virginia. He fought in the Revolutionary War (most notably at the Battle of Kings Mountain) and was later involved in the short-lived State of Franklin and the campaign for Tennessee statehood. When Sevier became Tennessee's first governor in 1796, he settled in South Knox County. Here, he constructed "Marble Springs Plantation," which consisted of a main building (shown) and several smaller outbuildings. Sevier died in Alabama in 1815 and was removed to the Knox County Courthouse lawn in 1889. His wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried nearby.

titleInfo.title: Civic Building and Southern Railway Depot

mods.abstract: Front of a souvenir postcard folder showing Knoxville's Civic Building and Southern Railway Station. The Station was built in Knoxville in 1904. It prospered until passenger traffic began to decline in the 1960s due to competition from airplanes and automobiles. The last passenger train to pass through the station was the "Birmingham Special," which departed on August 12, 1970. The station was renovated in the early 1990s for use by Knoxville architectural firm Bullock, Smith, and Partners, Inc.

mods.abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

mods.abstract: The Gay Street Viaduct was constructed in 1919 when the street's north end was raised by 15 feet. A number of shops moved to locations under the new viaduct, where they prospered for many years. Unfortunately, the structure gradually fell into disrepair and was closed for demolition in November of 2005. It was replaced by a concrete viaduct in late 2006, which remains in use today.

mods.abstract: Knoxville's Masonic Temple was originally Charles McClung McGhee's private home. The structure was designed by architect Joseph F. Baumann in 1872 and altered to serve as the Masonic Temple after McGhee's death in 1907. The interior of the home was restored in the early 1990s.

The First Baptist Church moved to their second home (made possible in large part by merchant and philanthropist W.W. Woodruff) in 1888. recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Knoxville Banking and Trust constructed this building, best known as the Holston National Bank Building, in 1912. At 12 stories, it was Knoxville's tallest edifice until 1928, when it was surpassed by the Andrew Johnson Building. The Holston National Bank became the Holston-Union Bank in 1928 and the Hamilton National Bank (now known as the First Tennessee Bank) in 1931. Although the Holston no longer serves the financial industry, it has been repurposed as a luxury residence building and continues to be a prominent Knoxville landmark.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay and Clinch (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. The Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

titleInfo.title: View of the Cherokee Country Club and the Horseshoe Bend

mods.abstract: The Cherokee Country Club's original clubhouse (shown here) was constructed in 1907. This structure was demolished in 1928 to make way for a more elaborate clubhouse designed by Knoxville architects Baumann and Baumann. The Tennessee River's Horseshoe Bend (today a National Military Park commemorating the Battle of Horseshoe Bend fought there on March 27, 1814) is shown as it appears from the clubhouse.

mods.abstract: Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J.Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. It was intended to provide a cultural education and enjoyed a reputation as one of the South's best schools. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s, and now houses a number of educational programs including adult education, the adult high school, GED testing, and continuing education.

mods.abstract: Completed in 1874, Knoxville's Post Office and Custom House may have been the city's first building to be designed by a professional architect, in this case Alfred B. Mullett. The structure was enlarged in 1910 and operated until a new Post Office was constructed in 1934. The TVA occupied the building until 1976, when it was restored and repurposed as the East Tennessee Historical Center.

mods.abstract: River traffic has flowed through East Tennessee since the area was settled in the late 18th century. The TVA operated Knoxville's Public Terminal (located on Neyland Drive) from 1944 to 1952, when it was leased to private interests. In 1962, the terminal was sold and became a for-hire facility.

Although the dam is located in Tennessee, much of the lake extends into northern Alabama where it covers a large portion of Muscle Shoals and so makes the Tennessee River much easier to navigate.

titleInfo.title: Knoxville Sentinel Building during the World Series

mods.abstract: In the 1920s, the Knoxville Sentinel maintained a board that allowed fans to keep up with the World Series game. It was manned by two boys: one (seen near the policeman's perch) relayed news to the crowd via megaphone, and the other (seen at the bottom of the board) updated the posted score. In this 1921 event, the Giants beat the Yankees 5-3.

titleInfo.title: Knoxville Electric Company (622 South Gay Street)

mods.abstract: The Knoxville Electric Light and Power Company was organized in 1888. It acquired the Mutual Light & Power Company in 1898, and was itself merged into the Knoxville Railway and Light Company (later known as the Tennessee Public Service Company) in 1905. Knoxville's municipal utility, the Knoxville Electric Power and Water Board, was established in 1939 and is now known as the Knoxville Utilities Board (KUB). This image also provides an excellent view of one of the perches that policemen used to control traffic in the 1920s.

This fire, which occurred on April 7, 1897, started in the Hotel Knox and consumed most of the 400 block of Gay Street before being stopped at the Sanford, Chamberlain & Albers Company Building with a firewall. The fire killed three people and a rare white mule (visiting Knoxville with an itinerant circus). The mule's ghost is said to have started a number of small fires in the area since.

mods.abstract: The Gay Street Viaduct was constructed in 1919 when the street's north end was raised by 15 feet. A number of shops moved to locations under the new viaduct, where they prospered for many years. Unfortunately, the structure gradually fell into disrepair and was closed for demolition in November of 2005. It was replaced by a concrete viaduct in late 2006, which remains in use today.

titleInfo.title: Rutherford B. Hayes speaking at the Lamar House

mods.abstract: When President Rutherford B. Hayes visited Knoxville in 1877, he was honored by a reception at the Lamar House. This establishment was built in 1817, and the Bijou Theatre opened as part of the hotel on March 8, 1909. Over the years, it hosted many famous vaudeville and theater acts. By 2005, however, the Theater was deteriorating and its owners defaulted on their mortgage. Knoxvillians, including Mayor Bill Haslam, banded together to save the Theater and fundraising and renovation efforts are ongoing.

titleInfo.title: World's Fair grounds (including the Sunsphere, the U.S. Pavilion, and the amphitheater)

mods.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.
